title: "Love Me or Burn?" Why THIS Analogy Doesn't Work for God
description:
Wow. Over half a million people thought this was a clever takedown.
It wasnâ€™tâ€”and hereâ€™s why.
The atheist in this video is making an argument from analogy. Thatâ€™s when you point to similarities between two things to argue that whatâ€™s true of one must also be true of the other.
In this case: If a husband says to his wife, â€˜Love me or Iâ€™ll set you on fire,â€™ we should all agree heâ€™s unloving.
So if God says, â€˜Love me or go to Hell,â€™ â€¦ we should all agree He must be unloving too. 
See how this works? It sounds powerfulâ€”but it fails badly. Why? Because for an argument from analogy to work, the similarities must be meaningful and the differences must be superficial. However, if there are significant differences, then itâ€™s a false analogy, and the whole argument falls apart. 
And thatâ€™s exactly what happens here. Here are three reasons this is a false analogy.

title: Did Mark's Gospel Forget the Resurrection? Nope!
description:
There is a lot misinformation being thrown around here. Yes, there is a long ending of Mark. But the long ending of Mark is not 21 verses. Itâ€™s 12 verses. Specifically, Mark 16:9-20.
And, yes, in those verses, we have a description of Jesus appearing to his followers (like Mary Magdalene, two disciples on the road, likely to Emmaus, and the eleven disciples). However, we DO have Jesusâ€™ resurrection in the earliest manuscripts of Mark (before the so-called long ending).
In fact, look at the verses they just highlighted in their video. It says, â€œYou are looking for Jesus the Nazarene, who was crucified. He has been rised! He is not here.â€ 
What verse is that? Verse 6. Thatâ€™s not part of the long ending. 
So, while telling us Markâ€™s Gospel doesnâ€™t contains Jesusâ€™ resurrection, the video literally highlights for us where Markâ€™s Gospel explicitly says Jesus has been raised. 
Again, this doesnâ€™t give the full story. While the earliest surviving manuscript with the long ending, Codex Alexandrinus comes from the 5th century, the long ending was not invented in the fifth century. Irenaeus in the second century refers to the longer ending of Mark, suggesting that by his time, the long ending was in circulation.
Itâ€™s ironic that a video trying to expose the most blatant misconception of Christianity gives us a blatant misconception of Christianity.

title: Pastor FINDS Christmas Trees in the Bible
description:
Does the Bible condemn Christmas trees? Some think so. And they cite Jeremiah 10:1-4 as proof. But hereâ€™s three reasons why that wonâ€™t work.

First, the context of Jeremiah 10 makes it clear that this is about carved idols, not Christmas trees. When you read the entire chapter (which you should do, right now!), it becomes obvious that Jeremiah is contrasting pagan idolsâ€”false godsâ€”made by the craftsman and the goldsmith (v. 3, 9, 14) and Yahwehâ€”the true Godâ€”who made the heavens and the earth (v. 12, 16). 

Folks, context matters. The only way to find a Christmas tree in Jeremiah 10 is to read it into the text and completely ignore the context. Thatâ€™s not good Bible study.

Second, the description in Jeremiah 10 fits a handcrafted idol, not a Christmas tree. After the tree is cut down, it is â€œworked with an axe by the hands of a craftsman (v. 3). Notice the wood is being carved into something, which is exactly how an idol gets made. 

Later in verse 8, Jeremiah says these idols â€œare both stupid and foolish; the instruction of idols is but wood!â€ In verse 5, the idol is compared to a scarecrow, which has a mouth and legs but cannot talk or walk. Again, this fits a description of an impotent idol that may have human features like a mouth or legs, but canâ€™t actually do anything. This is certainly not the description of a Christmas tree.

Third, reading a Christmas tree into Jeremiah 10 is anachronistic. An anachronism is attributing a custom, event, or object to a time period where it doesnâ€™t belong. There is no evidence that Christmas trees date back to a pagan ritual in Jeremiahâ€™s day. The best evidence we have traces Christmas trees back to the Middle Ages. So, reading Christmas trees into the time of the prophet Jeremiah wonâ€™t work.

Jeremiah 10 is not talking about Christmas trees.

title: Does JESUS Have a God? Responding to a Common Muslim Objection
description:
In todayâ€™s video, weâ€™re responding to a talking Bible and Quran. Isnâ€™t the Internet awesome? Actually, weâ€™re responding to the claim that Jesus cannot be God because He refers to God as â€œMy God.â€ 

For example, after his resurrection, Jesus tells Mary, â€œI am ascending to my Father and your Father, to my God and your God.â€ (John 20:17). There. Case-closed. Rest in peace, Christianity. 

Well, not so fast.

Iâ€™ve said it before but I will say it again: If youâ€™re going to challenge Christian theology, then you should try to understand Christian theology. This argument ignores two core Christian beliefsâ€”the Trinity and the incarnation. 

First, Christians believe in one God, who exists as three persons: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. Each is fully God, sharing the same divine essence, but each is a distinct Person. So the Father is God. The Son is God. And the Holy Spirit is God. 

Second, Christians hold that the Son, who is God, took on a human nature without ceasing to be God. He is fully human and fully divine. 

Okay, why is all this theology important? Because it helps understand how Jesus can pray and refer to God and, yet, still be God. When Jesus said â€œMy God,â€ he is referring to the Father. And the reason itâ€™s entirely appropriate for Jesus to speak of God the Father as â€œMy Godâ€ is because Jesus is fully human. In his humanity, Jesus is a perfect man, who honors, obeys, and prays to God the Father. 

So, Jesusâ€™ reference to â€œMy Godâ€ doesnâ€™t deny His own divinity. Instead, it reflects His humanity. Remember, in the incarnation, the Son sets aside His independent authority and heavenly glory. Philippians 2 tells us that Jesus, though in nature God, humbled Himself, taking on the form of a servant. But this voluntary humility doesnâ€™t negate His divinity.

Well, doesnâ€™t the Bible and the Quran both call Jesus a prophet?

While itâ€™s true that Jesus is called a prophet in both the Bible and the Quran, the Bible says a lot more than that! The Bible also teaches that Jesus fulfills many roles: prophet, priest, Messiah, king, and Savior. True, John 20:17 records Jesus saying to the Father, â€œMy God.â€ But, in John 20:28, just 11 verses later, Thomas calls Jesus, â€œMy Lord and my God.â€ Or, in John 8:58, Jesus says, â€œBefore Abraham was, I am,â€ claiming the divine name for Himself. My point is, this video sets up a false dilemma: either Jesus is God, or Heâ€™s just a prophet. But, in reality, Heâ€™s both.

What do you think? Do you find this argument compelling? Let me know.

title: Does Hell REFUTE an All-Knowing, All-Good God?
description:
This video lays out a challenge for Christians who believe in both Hell and an all-knowing, all-loving, and all-powerful God. Hereâ€™s the gist:   

If an all-knowing God creates people that He knows will go to Hell, then those people donâ€™t have free will. And if they donâ€™t have free will, then God is sending them to Hell for no fault of their own. Since that is incompatible with a good God, then, therefore, Hell is incompatible with an all-knowing and all-good God.

At the heart of this challenge is a fundamental error in thinking. More specifically, this challenge has a mistaken understanding of how Godâ€™s foreknowledge works. It assumes Godâ€™s foreknowledge somehow causes my actions. And if it causes my actions, then Iâ€™m not free.

But Godâ€™s foreknowledge doesnâ€™t cause what will happen. Rather, it reports what will happen. Thatâ€™s a really important difference. Itâ€™s not Godâ€™s knowledge of my future actions that cause my future actions. Rather, itâ€™s my actions that ground Godâ€™s knowledge.

title: Did this Muslim DEBUNK the Trinity in 30 Seconds?
description:
The Muslim in this video clearly thinks this was a â€œGotcha!â€ moment. In fact, the video is titled Trinity debunked in 30 seconds. Wow! Thatâ€™s a pretty big claim. So, letâ€™s pull out the Red Pen and see if it works.

Itâ€™s not surprising why this argument is so appealing. After all, it seems to show how Christians affirm two contradictory ideas. On the one hand, if we say that Jesus is God, then he must also believe God can die because Jesus died. On the other hand, if we say that God canâ€™t die, then Jesus canâ€™t be God because Jesus died.

So, whatâ€™s wrong with this argument? This reasoning relies on an equivocation of the word â€˜die.â€™ An equivocation, for you logic nerds, is the fallacy of using a word in two different senses in an argument. 

In this case, the word â€˜dieâ€™ is being used in two different senses. Websterâ€™s dictionary defines die as â€˜pass from physical life.â€™ But it also defines die as â€˜pass out of existence.â€™ 

If this Muslim asked me, â€œCan God die?â€ I would reply, â€œIt depends on what you mean by â€˜dieâ€™ and it depends on what you mean by â€˜God.â€™â€ You see, when terms are not clearly defined, people can end up talking in circles. (This video is case in point).

So, can God die? Well, God cannot cease to exist. In that sense, God cannot die. What about that other sense? Can God die physically? Well, a non-physical God canâ€™t die physically. Since Christians believe God the Father and God the Spirit are not physical, they cannot die in that sense either. 

However, Christians hold that God the Son took on flesh and dwelt among us (as John says). The one divine Person of Jesus has two distinct natures: a fully human nature and a fully divine nature. This is called the hypostatic union. And, itâ€™s because of the hypostatic union, that everything experienced in the two natures of Christ must be said to be experienced by the one, divine Person. So, the divine Person of Christ, for example, learned to walk and talk since he is the subject of everything experienced through his two natures.

Okay, so can God die? Well, if weâ€™re talking about God the Son incarnate and if weâ€™re talking about physical death (not ceasing to exist), then, yes, in that sense, God can and did die!

title: How do we know what the New Testament authors wrote?

Are Jesus' Resurrection Appearances a Later Mythological Development?
description:
Alex Oâ€™Connor is one of the most interesting and thoughtful atheists on the Internet. I always enjoy watching his stuff. While Iâ€™ve learned a lot from watching his videos, I think there are two significant problems in what he says. 

First, the idea that resurrection appearances are merely the product of mythological development over time is significantly undermined by an early creed found in First Corinthians 15. While First Corinthians was written early 50â€™s (which pre-dates Markâ€™s Gospel), it contains an early oral creed that likely goes back to within 5 years of the death of Jesus. Granted, these appearances read more like a shopping list than elaborate stories. My point is, there are five different appearances (plus Paul) recorded before Mark writes his Gospel. This historical fact does not fit well with the idea that resurrection appearances are the result of mythological development over time as you move further away from the source.

So, thatâ€™s the first problem. Here's the second problem. Alex is wrong about the moral lesson in Johnâ€™s Gospel. Alex says Johnâ€™s Gospel culminates with the story of Doubting Thomas to communicate the moral lesson to believe without evidence.

However, thatâ€™s not what the account is about. This account isnâ€™t against evidence for faith. In fact, this account is part of the evidence for faith. Itâ€™s ironic that people pick the story of doubting Thomas to show that evidence and belief are at odds since John includes the story for one simple reason: to provide evidence for belief. As John says, â€œThese are written so you would believe.â€

title: LGBT Advocate Argues Jesus Was Trans | Red Pen Rants
description:
A meme circulating on social media presents a dilemma: Either Jesus is trans, or Mary is intersex. It suggests that if Jesus inherited all his human DNA from Mary, he would have had to inherit an XX chromosome pattern, implying that he was trans. Conversely, if Mary was XY but still able to bear a child, it would suggest she was intersex.

In this video, we explore why this meme's claim is not just a humorous take but a flawed argument. We delve into the assumption that Jesus had to inherit all his DNA from Mary, dismissing the miraculous aspect of the incarnation. If God can create the universe from nothing, itâ€™s not a stretch to believe He could create a Y-chromosome or a male zygote without relying solely on Mary's genetic material.

Join us as we examine the theological implications of this meme and explain why viewing the incarnation as a miracle negates this dilemma. We also discuss the broader implications of understanding God as Creator and the importance of recognizing the divine nature of Jesus's birth.

Whether you're interested in debunking popular misconceptions or simply curious about the theology behind the incarnation, this video will offer you insights and a deeper understanding of the biblical perspective. Don't forget to like, comment, and subscribe for more thought-provoking content.

title: A Fundamental Flaw of Deconstruction
description:
While these deconstructionists accurately describe deconstruction, they highlight one of the fundamental flaws in the process. Deconstruction has no right way to do it and no right destination. This assumes there is no objective truth when it comes to religious beliefs.

However, Jesus disagrees. In his famous Sermon on the Mount, He says, â€œEnter through the narrow gate; for the gate is wide and the way is broad that leads to destruction, and there are many who enter through it. For the gate is small and the way is narrow that leads to life, and there are few who find itâ€ (Matt. 7:13â€“14).

First, notice Jesus mentions two ways. There is a narrow way and a broad way, a right way and a wrong way. Second, notice Jesus mentions two destinations. The right way leads to a good destination: life. The wrong way leads to a bad destination: Jesus calls it destruction. According to Jesus, there is absolutely a right place to land, and Jesus tells us how to get there.

title: Bible Scholar Thinks THIS is a Bible Contradiction
description:
In this video, New Testament scholar Bart Ehrman offers Alex Oâ€™Connor an example of what he believes to be an irreconcilable contradiction in the Christmas account. 

While Matthew and Luke give some different details, itâ€™s not clear that this amounts to a genuine contradiction. Hereâ€™s why. 

For this to be a genuine contradiction, the reader must assume two things. 
First, they assume silence about an event is a denial of an event. But this is a textbook example of an argument from silence: trying to reason from what a source does not say to the conclusion that something did not happen.

Second, the reader assumes Lukeâ€™s describing immediate, consecutive events.

Luke does say that Mary, Joseph, and Jesus returned to Nazareth, and he says it was after making sacrifices for ritual purification in Jerusalem. But was it immediately after, or eventually after? 

So, can these two accounts be reconciled? Yes. And I donâ€™t think itâ€™s terribly hard to see how. 

Mary and Joseph travel to Bethlehem, Jesus is born and the shepherds visit. Forty days after Jesus was born, they go to the Temple in Jerusalem to fulfill the Law. Then, they return to their home in Bethlehem. They meet the magi. Then, after being warned in a dream about Herodâ€™s plot, Mary, Joseph, and Jesus flee to Egypt to escape. When Herod is dead, they begin traveling back to Judea, but after being warned in another dream, they go to Nazareth instead.

title: Responding to Someone Who WANTS to Go to Hell
description:
How should Christians respond to someone who says they want to go to Hell? Here are some quick thoughts.

First, itâ€™s completely appropriate for Christians to warn people of the coming judgment. After all, Jesus did. In fact, Jesus uses some pretty graphic imagery when he tells people itâ€™s better to pluck out your eye or cut off your hand if they cause you to sin than to be cast into Hell. 

Think of it this way. Just as any decent person would warn someone of the dangers of taking cocaine, any decent Christian, who believes in a real coming judgment, should warn others of the dangers of sin.

This raises a question, when do we give up on warning people? This leads to my second point: Christian, itâ€™s not your job to save people. Warn people? Yes. Correct people? Sure. Share the gospel? Absolutely. But there comes a time when youâ€™ve done or said all you can. You canâ€™t force someone to follow Jesus.

Third, if youâ€™re going to respond to someoneâ€™s public posts, remember to speak truth with grace. In other words, donâ€™t be a jerk. Let me do my best to model that with a response to her first challenge.

title: Ex-Christian Musician CHALLENGES How Jesus Can be the ONLY WAY to God
description:
If youâ€™re going to critique a view, itâ€™s important to accurately represent the view. In this video, former Christian music artist Michael Gungor offers an analogy that he thinks describes Christian exclusivismâ€”the idea that faith in Jesus is the only way of salvation. 

Unfortunately, Gungorâ€™s water bottle analogy is fundamentally flawed in at least two ways. First, his analogy assumes all religions are fundamentally the same. Notice how while one water bottle has a superficial differenceâ€”a pink bowâ€”they each contains the exact same thingâ€”water. So, if you were thirsty, it wouldnâ€™t really matter which bottle you drank from. In fact, it would be absurd for someone to demand you drink from the one with a pink bow. Ironically, this analogy more accurately describes religious pluralismâ€”the view that all religions are equally validâ€”than exclusivism.

This leads to the second fundamental flaw. The water bottle analogy fails to account for why Jesus is the only way of salvation. After all, thereâ€™s no good justification for why someone needs to drink from the water bottle with the pink bow.

title: Youâ€™re just trying to control women. #shorts
description:
Have you seen statements like this on social media? Iâ€™ve been seeing this everywhere in the abortion debate. Itâ€™s a clever ploy to distract from the real issue.

Hereâ€™s how it works. You assume a person is wrong, then jump immediately to explaining why they are wrong. So, you attack their motives, not their argument. C. S. Lewis called this â€œbulverism.â€ And itâ€™s rampant today.

Imagine I said to you, â€œThe Earth is round.â€ And you replied, â€œYouâ€™re just saying that because . . . youâ€™re a Western, white man.â€

Notice this response doesnâ€™t refute my claim. Rather, it assumes Iâ€™m wrong and moves on to trying to explain why I made the claim.

Hereâ€™s the problem with this thinking: Before you explain why someone is wrong, you must show that they are wrong.

Once you understand the â€œbulverismâ€ fallacy, youâ€™re going to start to see it everywhere.

description:

First, you canâ€™t prohibit someone from legislating their moral beliefs since all laws legislate someoneâ€™s moral beliefs. Thatâ€™s how the legislative process works. 

Second, not all beliefs held by religious people are strictly religious beliefs. This distinction is really important since some want to simply label a belief as â€œreligiousâ€ just so they can reject it. As it turns out, no one is trying to legislate strictly religious beliefs. And the examples typically given as religious beliefs are held with equal confidence by non-religious people.

title: God DOES Give You More Than You Can Handle
description:
In todayâ€™s tweet, Joel Osteen offers a familiar slogan. He says, "God will not give you more than you can handle. If you have a big challenge today, that means you have a big destiny."

First, Osteenâ€™s catchphrase creates confusion. It sounds like God wonâ€™t let terrible circumstances befall you. But thatâ€™s not true. God never promises we will escape the difficulties of life. Jesus promises just the oppositeâ€”tribulation.

Second, even though our circumstances may feel overwhelming, God is still good. Because He has not left us, we can rely on him. In fact, he has promised to work all things together for good for those called according to his purpose.

Third, some might be thinking, what about 1 Corinthians 10:13? Two quick thoughts. First, this second passage is about temptations, not trials. When we look at the context, Paul warns the Church not to fall for the same temptations the Israelites fell for. They engaged in idolatry (v. 7), sexual immorality (v. 8), and grumbling (v. 10). 

Paulâ€™s point in 1 Cor. 10 is clear. We experience temptation just like the Israelites did. But with every temptation, God faithfully provides a way of escape from the temptation so weâ€™ll able to endure it. In other words, God has given us the ability to beat the temptation with the help of the Spirit.

First, godFreeWorld is just plain wrong about the facts. It turns out that most of the fathers of modern scienceâ€”you know, the guys with laws named after themâ€”were Christians.

title: Worst Pro-Choice Argument I've EVER Seen
description:
K Hole Adventurer uses an analogy to show that the pro-lifeÂ position is sillyâ€”that itâ€™s kind ofÂ like arguing for the rights of a worm. Now, an argumentÂ from analogy is a special kind of inductive argument. Basically, it reasons that because two things are similar, what is true of the first is also true of the second.Â 

Of course, no analogy is perfectâ€”there will always be differences. But for an argument from analogy to work, the similarities have to be significant and the differences have to be superficial. But if the opposite is trueâ€”if the differences are significant and the similarities are superficialâ€”well, then, we have a problem.

Unfortunately for K Hole, this is a false analogy. The argument doesnâ€™t work because tapeworms and humans are really different. The similarities are superficial, but the difference is a big deal. And you already know what it is. Itâ€™s the difference between the value of worms and the value of humans. Killing a worm is not the same as killing a human being.

But thereâ€™s a second problem. The analogy misunderstands the pro-life argument. We are not saying that anything inside your body with a heartbeat that feels pain has a right to life. We are not pro-life because something has a heartbeat, or feels pain, or is inside your body. We are pro-life because abortion kills a human being inside her own motherâ€™s body. Our argument is that human beings at any stage of development have intrinsic value and should not be killed.Â 

So, the tweet uses a faulty analogy to argue thereâ€™s an inconsistency in the pro-life view. But there is nothing inconsistent about pro-lifers being against killing human beings who are intrinsically valuable and being for killing tapeworms because theyâ€™re just worms. Get it?

title: Jesus Mythicist Finds No Evidence Jesus Existed AFTER EXCLUDING Evidence He Existed
description:
You may be surprised to hear that some people think Jesus never existed. They believe Jesus is a mere myth with no historical evidence to back him up. Hereâ€™s the problem. First, the claim that we have no documentation for Jesusâ€™ existence outside the Bible is just plain false. Authors like Tacitus, Josephus, and Lucian and others all make reference to Jesusâ€”a historical person. 

Second, even if we didnâ€™t have any extra-biblical evidence, so what? We still have reliable historical documentation from early witnesses collected together in the book we now call the Bible. Only a blind-eyed bias against the Bible would dismiss this early evidence for Jesus. 

Though popular on the Internet, the idea that Jesus never existed completely ignores the facts. In the introduction of Bart Ehrmanâ€™s book Did Jesus Exist?, he says, 

â€œI am not a Christian, and I have no interest in promoting a Christian cause or a Christian agenda. I am an agnostic with atheist leanings . . . But as a historian I think evidence matters. And the past matters. And for anyone to whom both evidence and the past matter, a dispassionate consideration of the case makes it quite plain: Jesus did exist.â€

title: The Bible Doesnâ€™t Say What He Thinks It Says

title: Christians Are Really Atheistsâ€”Kinda, Sorta, Not Really
description:
It has become increasingly commonâ€”especially on the Internetâ€”to hear atheists say, â€œChristians are atheists too. Theyâ€™re just atheists of one less god than me.â€ The â€œone less godâ€ heâ€™s referring to is, of course, Yahweh. In other words, the Christian is an atheist who believes in one God.

If that sounds weird, it should. First, it just makes no sense to call a Christian an atheist of any kind. Thatâ€™s a misuse of the word. It's akin to calling a married man, like me, a bachelor with one wife.

Second, pointing out that Christians and atheists both reject a pantheon of gods is a clever move, but tells us nothing about the existence of the Christian God. Christians reject the pantheon for the same reason atheists do: no evidence. And they accept the God of Christianity because there is good evidence. Itâ€™s that simple! 

Third, the next time you hear some say â€œYouâ€™re an atheist of one less god than meâ€ move towards the objection, not away from it. That is, just agree with them, then point out its irrelevance. Say something like, â€œYouâ€™re right, I am an atheist regarding every other god. Now what?â€ This neutralizes their rhetorical move, and directs the discussion where it belongs: on the evidence for the Christian God. 

Class dismissed.

title: Pro-Choicer Thinks Jesusâ€™ Silence on Abortion Affirms Abortion...It Doesnâ€™t!
description:

Hereâ€™s her logic: If Jesus didnâ€™t mention the unborn, then they didnâ€™t matter to Him. And if they didnâ€™t matter to Him, they shouldnâ€™t matter to us.

There are actually three fatal flaws in this approach. First, even if it is true that Jesus didnâ€™t say anything about the unborn (and we donâ€™t actually know that), nothing logically follows from it. We certainly cannot concludeâ€”as Pam Keith impliesâ€”that the unborn didnâ€™t matter to Jesus. Thatâ€™s a textbook example of a fallacious argument from silence.

Second, Jesus clearly did say a lot about the authority of the Old Testament. And the Old Testament affirms the value and dignity of human beings before they are born. Therefore it's reasonable to think Jesus would affirm their dignity and value, too.

Third, in the New Testament, even Jesus and John are treated as themselvesâ€”genuine, complete, valuable human beingsâ€”while they are still in utero.

title: Atheist Says God Isnâ€™t All-Powerful Unless He DEFEATS Himself
description:
In todayâ€™s example, molecular biologist Mark Dâ€™Arcy offers a question meant to challenge the idea of an omnipotentâ€”that is, all powerfulâ€”God. The tweet reads: "Can God create a stone that cannot be lifted? If yes, then he is not all powerful since he Himself cannot lift it. If he cannot create a stone that cannot be lifted, then he is not all powerful. Either way, God is not all powerful."

This challenge is plagued with problems. First, omnipotence is not the power to do anything. Rather, itâ€™s the ability to do anything power can do. Even infinite power cannot do what is contradictory or absurd. This isnâ€™t a limit on Godâ€™s power. Itâ€™s a limit on the kinds of questions we should be asking about Godâ€™s power. 

Second, itâ€™s an illogical question. Thatâ€™s because it subtly smuggles in a contradiction by asking if Godâ€™s omnipotence can defeat His omnipotence. Itâ€™s like asking, â€œCan God win in arm wrestling match against Himself?â€ Itâ€™s nonsense. 

Ironically, in his attempt to show the incoherence of an omnipotent Creator, this atheist relies on an incoherent question.
